text: If you were kind of inside baseball with WordPress, it's actually a lot of people who have been unhappy with me over the years. Previously, 1% of the world thought I was terrible and now I feel like it's up to four or 5%.
speaker: Matt Mullenweg
context: Lenny asks Matt about how he deals with the negative sentiment from people who now see him as controversial due to the WP Engine dispute. Matt explains that while many people think he was universally beloved before this controversy, there have actually been critics within the WordPress community for years over various decisions like introducing new features. He's putting the current criticism in perspective by noting it's still a small percentage of people overall.
text_ko: WordPress 쪽 내부 사정(inside baseball)을 좀 아신다면, 사실 수년 동안 저에게 불만을 가진 사람들이 꽤 많았어요. 예전에는 전 세계의 1% 정도만 저를 형편없다고 생각했는데, 요즘은 4~5%까지 늘어난 것 같아요.
text_zh: 如果你对WordPress内部情况比较了解的话，其实这些年来对我不满的人挺多的。以前全世界只有1%的人觉得我很糟糕，现在我感觉已经涨到4%、5%了。
text_es: Si estabas al tanto de lo que pasaba internamente en WordPress, en realidad hay mucha gente que ha estado molesta conmigo a lo largo de los años. Antes, el 1% del mundo pensaba que era un desastre y ahora siento que ya subió al cuatro o 5%.

text: Since 2019, WP Engine has kind of changed a bit. They started using the trademark, they're offering something called WordPress. They're referred to it as like a bastardized hacked up version of it. It's diluting our brand.
speaker: Matt Mullenweg
context: Lenny asks Matt to explain the high-level overview of what's happening with WP Engine. Matt describes how WP Engine was acquired by private equity firm Silver Lake in 2019, and since then has been using WordPress trademarks inappropriately while offering a modified version of WordPress that removes key features like post revisions to save money. This creates brand confusion and dilutes the WordPress trademark.
text_ko: 2019년 이후로 WP Engine이 좀 달라졌어요. 상표(trademark)를 쓰기 시작했고, 워드프레스(WordPress)라는 걸 서비스로 내놓더라고요. 사람들은 그걸 원형을 훼손한, 엉망으로 뜯어고친 변형판이라고 부르더라고요. 그래서 우리 브랜드가 희석되고 있어요.
text_zh: 从2019年开始，WP Engine这家公司有点变味儿了。他们开始打我们商标的擦边球，搞了个什么WordPress的服务。说白了就是把我们的东西改得乱七八糟的，完全是个四不像的山寨版。这不是在砸我们品牌的招牌吗。
text_es: Desde 2019, WP Engine como que ha cambiado un poco. Empezaron a usar la marca registrada, están ofreciendo algo que llaman WordPress. Se refieren a eso como una versión bastardizada y pirateada. Está diluyendo nuestra marca.

text: If you're really open and open source, sometimes you have to stand up the bullies and you have to fight to protect your open source ideals. Otherwise people could take advantage of it in a way that ultimately can destroy everything you've created.
speaker: Matt Mullenweg
context: Matt explains why he took a confrontational approach with WP Engine despite his usual collaborative style. He's addressing criticism that he's become mean or aggressive, arguing that protecting open source principles sometimes requires standing up to companies that would exploit the open nature of these projects. He believes that failing to defend against such exploitation could ultimately harm the entire open source ecosystem he's spent decades building.
text_ko: 정말로 개방적이고 오픈 소스(open source)라면, 때로는 횡포를 부리는 사람들에게 단호히 맞서 싸워서 그 오픈 소스 가치를 지켜야 해요. 안 그러면 사람들이 그걸 부당하게 이용해서 결국 지금까지 쌓아온 모든 걸 망가뜨릴 수 있어요.
text_zh: 如果你真的要做开放和开源(open source)，有时候就得跟那些欺负人的较较真，得为了保护你的开源理念去争取。不然的话，别人就会钻空子，最后可能把你辛辛苦苦建起来的东西全给毁了。
text_es: Si realmente estás comprometido con el código abierto (open source), a veces tienes que plantarles cara a los abusivos y luchar para proteger tus ideales de código abierto. Si no, la gente puede aprovecharse de una manera que al final puede destruir todo lo que has construido.

text: A lie gets around the world seven times before the truth has time to get out of bed.
speaker: Matt Mullenweg
context: Lenny asks why so many people view Matt as the bad guy in the WP Engine controversy. Matt responds with this classic saying to explain how misinformation can spread much faster than corrections on social media. He's suggesting that false narratives about the situation have gained more traction than the actual facts, particularly on platforms like Twitter where controversial content gets promoted by algorithms.
text_ko: 거짓말은 진실이 침대에서 나오기도 전에 이미 세상을 일곱 번이나 돈다고 해요.
text_zh: 假消息满天飞的时候，真相还没来得及澄清呢。
text_es: Una mentira ya le ha dado siete vueltas al mundo mientras la verdad todavía se está levantando de la cama.

text: Don't just build a product, build a movement. And to the extent that we've been successful, I think it's that we give people something to believe in, a philosophy, a worldview.
speaker: Matt Mullenweg
context: Lenny asks Matt about lessons learned from building one of the most successful online communities around WordPress. Matt shares his core philosophy for community building, explaining that successful projects need more than just utility - they need to inspire people with a deeper purpose and philosophy. He attributes WordPress's success to giving people open source ideals to believe in, not just software to use.
text_ko: 그냥 제품만 만들지 말고, 무브먼트(movement)를 만들어야 해요. 우리가 어느 정도 성공할 수 있었던 건 사람들이 믿을 수 있는 무언가, 즉 하나의 철학이나 세계관을 제시해 줬기 때문이라고 생각해요.
text_zh: 不要只是做产品，要做一场运动。我觉得我们之前成功的原因，就是给了大家一个信念，一套理念，一种世界观。
text_es: No se trata solo de crear un producto, sino de crear un movimiento. Y en la medida en que hemos tenido éxito, creo que es porque les damos a las personas algo en lo que creer, una filosofía, una forma de ver el mundo.

text: It's not just the software, it's also like: how are the meetups? How are people getting together? What events are you running? Are there forums? How do people contribute? Is there office hours or town halls?
speaker: Matt Mullenweg
context: Matt continues explaining his community-building philosophy, emphasizing that successful open source projects require much more than just good software. He's describing the comprehensive ecosystem needed around a product - events, forums, contribution opportunities, and regular communication channels. This holistic approach to community building has been key to WordPress's success in creating engaged contributors and users.
text_ko: 단순히 소프트웨어만의 문제가 아니에요. 밋업(meetups)은 어떤가요? 사람들이 어떻게 모이나요? 어떤 이벤트를 운영하고 있나요? 포럼(forums)은 있나요? 사람들은 어떻게 기여하나요? 오피스 아워(office hours)나 타운홀(town halls)은 있나요?
text_zh: 不光是软件本身的问题，还有比如说：线下聚会(meetup)办得怎么样？大家平时怎么聚在一起交流？你们都搞什么活动？有没有论坛？大家是怎么参与贡献的？有没有答疑时间(office hours)或者全员大会(town hall)这些？
text_es: No es solo el software, también es como: ¿qué tal están los meetups? ¿Cómo se está juntando la gente? ¿Qué eventos están organizando? ¿Hay foros? ¿Cómo contribuye la gente? ¿Tienen office hours o town halls?
